greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle T(n,k), n>=0, 0<=k<=n, read by rows: T(n,k) is the number of partitions of n containing a clique of size k.
comment: All parts of a number partition with the same value form a clique. The size of a clique is the number of elements in the clique. Each partition has a clique of size 0.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..140, flattened
example: T(5,2) = 2, because 2 (of 7) partitions of 5 contain (at least) one clique of size 2: [1,2,2], [1,1,3].
maple: b:= proc(n, i, k) option remember; `if`(n=0, [1, 0], `if`(i<1, [0, 0],
mathematica: b[n_, i_, k_] := b[n, i, k] = If[n == 0, {1, 0}, If[i < 1, {0, 0}, Sum[Function[l, If[j == k, {l[[1]], l[[1]]}, l]][b[n - i*j, i-1, k]], {j, 0, n/i}]] ]; t[n_, k_] := Function[l, l[[If[k == 0, 1, 2]]]][b[n, n, k]]; Table[Table[t[n, k], {k, 0, n}], {n, 0, 12}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 16 2013, translated from Maple *)
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Jan 05 2011
